definition:
[@steen; @willard] Suppose $X$ is a topological space. If $X$ has a
basis consising of clopen sets, then $X$ is said to be .

Examples of zero-dimensional spaces are: the set $\mathbb{Q}$ of
rational numbers (with subspace topology induced from the usual metric
topology on $\mathbb{R}$, the set of real numbers), the Cantor space, as
well as the Sorgenfrey line.

The concepts of zero-dimentionality and total disconnectedness are
closely related. Indeed, every zero-dimentional is totally disconnected.
Furthermore, if a topological space is locally compact and Hausdorff,
then the notions of zero-dimentionality and total disconnectedness are
equivalent.

[9]{} L.A. Steen, J.A.Seebach, Jr., *Counterexamples in topology*, Holt,
Rinehart and Winston, Inc., 1970. S. Willard, *General Topology*,
Addison-Wesley, Publishing Company, 1970.
